The Rainy season of 1875 + 6 set in about Oct 15 1875, and rained almost incessantly from that time till June 15 1876, by far the wettest winter ever experienced in Oregon since its first settlement, more rainy day, and the greatest depth of waterfall for any one year
June 5 1876. Was once more elected Clerk of Douglas County for a term of 2 years -- The Election was hotly contested, three full tickets being in the field. Republican, Democratic and Independent -- Republican ticket elected
Main Centennial celebration for the State was held at Portland, the Commercial Metropolis of Oregon on July 4, continued for one week! 
July 5th entered upon my duties as County Clerk of Douglas County ?Oregon? for a term of two years
[Along the side] June 2 3 was at Portland and visited the Central School ?Exhibition? program

November 7, 1876 Presidential Election
Oregon saw 1000 and upwards majority for Hayes and Wheeler, and Dick William for Congress - 
Hayes having one majority in the Electoral College, of course a great deal of filibustiry followed, based mainly upon technical items in the Election, and eligibility of the Electors chosen - and to settle all disputed points and to ensure a honest, and fair count and a legal as well as equitable decision of all doubtful points a committee was appointed by Congress, called the Electoral Commission. to make decisions when otherwise doubtful.
The Electoral Tribunal met the first  February 1877, and, were in session the most of the time until March 2d 1977 when at 4 oclock A.M. after an all night session the result was declared in accordance with the facts to wit 185 Electoral votes for Hayes and Wheeler and 184 for Tilden and Hendricks
The successful candidates being properly inaugurated on March 5 1877. the fourth being Sunday

2
1877
At the January term of the County Court . I was appointed a member of a County investigating committee to examine and correct errors in the County affairs.  G. J. Fuller & E. Stephens my predecessor were the other appointees - Report attached w this page

under Joseph and up to the present time, the Whites and Indians of that vicinity have been continually growling at each other . in a manner peculiar to the frontiers . with an occasional Indian [crossed out: and] or white being killed and stock being stolen

  The white settlers . always relying upon the Military for protection . probably endured much more than they would had they relied upon themselves - they were always willing to talk about the bad Indians, the renegade Joseph and others . but when opportunity often offered . they would as quietly let it pass and let Joseph and his murderous Companions pass also unharmed
   Having leisure and being in that vicinity a few years ago . I proposed to go out in company with a single individual . and find the cause of their great trouble & fear . and rid North Eastern Oregon of this pesk [sic] of the Wollowa
   The second day out we came suddenly upon this modern Joseph and two or three of his swarthy Companions . upon a small branch in a deep but very narrow vally . not over 30 yards from us.  Instictively [sic] I raised my rifle . and placed myself in a quick position in the attitude of firing . and in a second or two more expected to end the spirit of that poor red man to the happy hunting grounds . when all at once my Comrade from Cowardly Motives . or fear of the consequences caught my arm and commenced an excited Conversation . about the impropriety of

[newspaper clipping obscures portion of first six lines of this page]
[Newspaper clipping]
GATHERED TO HIS FATHERS  -  The familiar form and jovial countenance of Dr. E. R. Fiske will no more be seen on the streets of earth.  Last Monday night at 10 o'clock the good man passed from his home here to that 'home not made with hands, eternal in the heavens.'  Dr. Fiske has been quite feeble for many months, and his most intimate friends knew that his death was liable at any time, but many of his acquaintances will be surprised at his sudden decease.  He was confined to his room but a few days. - [Italics:  Statesman.]

  The Dr. was formerly a resident of this city and county where he leaves many old friends.

[Journal page]
On [obscured text] Dr. E. R. Fiske an old [Oreg... obscured text] the Capital of the State Dr [obscured text] Umpqua River in 1850 in [obscured text] "Samuel Roberts" . private [?] [obscured text] California for the settlement and [obscured text] valleys of southern Oregon

  An organized company under the name of "Winchester Paine & Co." came in the aforesaid vessel and attempted to do considerable for southern Oregon - they bargained for a part interest in Scottsburg, which had just been located by Capt Levi Scott . surveyed off townsides as Umpqua City . Gardner . Elkton at the mouth of Elk Creek 20 miles above Scottsburg . and Winchester, a point on the trail from Oregon to California where the same crosses the North Umpqua River . and for a brief period attracted considerable attention to this part of Oregon - Umpqua City - & Elkton failed entirely as towns - Winchester grew into considerable importance became the County seat of Douglas County . but was afterwards entirely abandoned . and all the buildings torn down & moved away - Gardner is now a brisk little place
  For want of means or some other cause "Winchester Paine & co" dissolved . or full [sic] to pieces and part of the Company returned to California and a portion remained and took part in the early settlement of the Umpqua Vally . and among them was Dr Fiske . who was the first man of that profession resident of Southern Oregon - He it was who attended upon me during my long and tedious sufferings from Indians arrow wounds received in Sept 1851 - He remained in the Umpqua Vally until about 1862 when he removed to Salem where he has since resided - In former years he was some what reckless and dissipated . but for the last 10 or 12 years has lived an upright & consistent Christian life

9
On August 29th 1877 Brigham Young the Mormon leader and the greatest fraud that ever lived upon this planet died at Salt Lake City in Utah Territory where he has resided since 1848-- There will probably be a great strife over the succession-- No other living person can ever so successfully control such an immense mass of ignorance under the guise of Religion-- It is perhaps unfortunate that he was permitted to live as long as he did and yet at this time it would been more satisfactory for him to have lived a little longer so as to have been tried and executed for some of the many crimes of which he has been guilty, and one particularly his part in the celebrating "Mountain Meadow" Masacre for which J.D. Lee one of his prime ministers & executive officers has recently been tried. Convicted and shot   
Brigham was the chief executive officer of the Mountain Meadow Masacre of 1857 He planned the masacre and Lee carried out his orders, as any other subordinate carries out the orders of his superior-- Who was the real guilty party. Lee who obeyed orders, or Brigham Young who issued the orders-- Lee has been executed, and death alone saved his superior Officer (Brigham) from a similar fate- Already implicated to such an extent that escape would been impossible  and just before the time for official proceedings to commence, he sickened and died. more likely from his own hand, than otherwise.

by the Indians with Tourists and visitors-- Following down the Yellow Stone,  Gen Sturgess who had been operating in the Sioux Country happened to be in their way, and a fight
ensued with considerable loss on each side. It was about a stand off-  The Indians now changed their course north or northwesterly through the muscle [unclear...] and crossed the Missouri River at a point somewhere between Fort Benton and Carroll two points on the River about 200 [unclear] River about Fort Benton being the extreme head of Navigation and Carroll the head of low water navigation.  
About half way from Carroll to Ft Benton at a point called Cow Island. where  Fort Benton freight is sometimes landed when Steamers fail to reach the latter place, the Indians or a detachment of them, learning that a quantity of freight was banked there succeeded in killing a few men who were guarding the same and after stealing and carrying away all they could, burned the balance--

  A few days, later about the 3,4 & 5 Oct 1877 Gen Miles another Montana General like Sturgess & Gibbon was watching the course of the Nez Pesces, and learning of their raid at Cow Island landing, set

The Nez Perce Indian War is over. Their retreat of 1200 miles and Howard's pursuit has been famous - Howard was never able to come up with the hostiles - He reached points very near them on several occasions, but failed to bring them to an engagement - After crossing the Bitter Root Mountains from near where the war commenced - the Indians surprised everyone by turning South Easterly instead of Northerly for British Territory Gen Gibbon of Montana met them at Big hole and had a severe fight - (See dispatches) afterwards the Indians passed out of the SE corner of Idaho crossed the Rocky Mts. entered the National Park, Howard in close pursuit 20 or 30 miles behind generally - In the Park at or near the Geyser Basin Some depredations were committed

out, and surprised them at the Bears Paw Mountains a day or two march from there and a fight of a day or two took place with quite severe losses on both sides. Which resulted in the surrender of the whole of Josephs Band - which took place 
Oct 5 1877
The Indians after leaving the Yellowstone River, evidently made as direct a march for the British line north as they could do and were captured by Gen Miles at the Bears Paw Mountains about a days ride from the northern boundary - General Howard with his pursuing? forces did not reach Gen Miles until the day of the Surrender when he arrived himself with a detachment of cavalry a few hours before the Indians raised the white flag & laid down their arms. The remains of the Command? coming up soon after

July 12 1878
Time being out in the clerks office and not being a candidate for reelection - and my successor having been qualified and entered upon his duties and having concluded to go into the eastern part of the Territory of Washington on a visit among friends who reside there - I set out this morning at 5 oclock on the Rail Road for Portland 200 miles distant, where I arrived at 5 P.M.
July 13 1878
Went on board the magnificent steamer "Wide West" and seemed down the Willamette River 12 miles and entered the Columbia, and then up stream to the Lower Cascades where we arrived at 10 A.M. made the portage by Rail Road as usual and again embarked on the Steamer "Mountain Queen" and arrived at "The Dalles" at 4 P.M. From there by cars to Celilo and went on board the Steamer "Annie Faxon" at 6 P.M.
July 14 1878
The Steamer set out up river a little before daylight and we reached Nallula at 4 oclock P.M. and thence to Walla Walla by Rail Road
July 15 1878
Took stage at Walla Walla for the north and at 10 A.M. was at the little town of Waitsburg - Here I procured a private conveyance and soon arrived at my old Friends. Mr G.H. Burtges? with whom I have been acquainted since the year 1852, and who together with his wife Mrs Emily Burtges? cared for me kindly during

a water tank where a certain saw mill company secured water from a small spring branch for Mill purposes, the water being hauled by the Mill led? about 4 miles
August 29 1878
sketch of claim described below, labeled T9crR40E
Took claim on SW/4 of S E/4
SE/4 of SW/4 sec/
NE/4 N.W/4
N.W/4 NW 1/4 of Sec 12
all in T9Cr.R.40E in Columbia Co. W.T.
a fine timbered claim, with some good farm land. 
August 30 1878
Returned to Mr Bartyes? they having hauled out 10 loads of wood for the winter myself performing the duties of Cook or Campman for them during this time
Sept. 3d 1878
Returned from Walla Walla where I had been on Land business for Mr Daniels
Dec. 3 - 1878
Set out for the Umpqua Vally and went as far as Waitsburg 6 miles and stopped for the night 
Dec. 4 1878
Reached Walla Walla in the afternoon having come over this far on a wagon, where I remained over the 5th
Dec. 6 1878
Went on board the R.R. Train at noon and

many years of sickness caused by Indian arrow wounds received in 1851 - Mr. B. was absent, having went down to the Willamette Valley in Western Oregon to purchase a band of sheep, and is now expected home in about two weeks -- Mrs B. was overseeing the farm work & her oldest daughter Agnes, no Mrs Daniels is living with them, her husband being on the way from the Willamette Valley with her father, driving sheep

August 6.Bartges arrived with sheep obscured
8 August 20 1878  obscured
Bartges. Mr Daniels & myself went to the mountains above the town of Dayton about 20 miles away to haul wood for winter use. We did not start very early, hence was obliged to camp by the Road side about 6 miles from the place where we expected to cut the timber
August 21 1878 
About 1/2 from where one camped last night we entered open pine land and for about 5 miles timber. becoming more dense all the way we camped at

15
opened, and warmer weather appeared - Snow is about 4 inches deep around the Docks? and the weather extremely cold. and we could not engage a passage by stage until
Monday Dec 30 1878
Piercing cold this morning, went on board the Stage at an early hour for Walla Walla, Mercury at Zero. the plains cold with unclear winds. Dinner & Breakfast a DesChutes River, and at night was at John Days River 45 miles from the Dallus with a fearful cold and blustering night before us
Tuesday Dec 31 1878
An all nights ride over the cold snowy plains the weather all the time becoming colder. and in a miserable condition we found ourselves at daylight at the Village of Hepner a small place of a dozen houses situated on the head of Willow Creek a tributary of the Columbia - Hepner has been built up in the last 4 or 5 years. is near the foot of the Blue Mountains, and is situated in the midst of a fine grazing & agricultural country --
An early start, and after rolling over the hard frozen road, near all day, crossing Butter Creek - Birch Creek and McKay creek we found ourselves at 3 P.M. at Pendleton the County seat of Umatilla County, a flourishing place of 300 population. built up in a few years on the South side of the Umatilla River - Here we stop for the night
Wednesday January 1 1879
Started quite early for Walla Walla passing Centerville on Wild Horse Creek

reached Wallula where we arrived late in the evening and went on board the Steamer "Almota" for the night. 
Dec 7 1878
Set out down River early. reached Cililo in due time and from thence to the Docks by Rail Road & remained until
Monday Dec 9 1878
Went on board the Steamer "Mountain Queen" for the Cascades, made the portage as usual and took the Steamer R.R. Thompson and reached Portland at dusk
Tuesday Dec 10 1878
Went on Train this morning early and was at Roseburg at 7.30 P.M. and remained there until
Thursday Dec 26 1878
Set out on my return to the Upper Country again. By R.R. I reached Portland at 5 oclock P.M
Friday Dec 27 1878
Set out from Portland punctual at 6 AM. on the Steamer "Emma Hayward" and was at the Lower Cascades at the usual hour. Made the Portage by Rail Road, thence on the "Mountain Queen" to the Docks where we arrived at 4 PM - Here the passengers for Walla Walla found, very much to their chagrin, that the vast amount of ice above and the cold freezing weather had caused the Steam navigation company to tie up their Boats at Cililo 15 miles above, and that no more Boats would go up River until the River

16
in large numbers to bid the prisoners a final farewell and to sing the songs and perform the ceremonies peculiar to their race? upon such occasions. 
The Sheriff of Umatilla County having the prisoners in charge, admitted the Umatillas to the Jail Yard where they immediately formed themselves into a circle, and the condemned prisoners. with manacles upon their limbs were let out - The "Medicine man" of the Trade made a short speech in the Indian language and several Indian songs were sung and chanted in plaintive tones - The Medicine man all the time occupying a place in the center of the Circle wringing a tinkling little bell above his head - at the conclusion of the several songs the prisoners passed along the inside of the circle of Indians. shaking hands with all and each one separately which consumed a half hours time, after which short speeches were made by the condemned prisoners, and the crowd of Indians in solemn and tearful procession passed out of the Jail Yard - 
These Barbarous ceremonies were quite solemn and impressive and the Indians were deeply affected. and in fact several white persons present only restrained their tears by the strongest efforts on their part
The people of this vicinity not having fully recovered from the panic of last summer and anticipating further trouble, and the Sheriff not feeling that everything was quite safe has called for 100 armed volunteers to be present, and General Howard of this Military Department has ordered two companies of Cavalry down from Walla Walla who are now encamped nearby. all of which forces, combined will render any attempt at an Indian attack abortive

and Weston on Pine Creek and Milton on the Walla Walla River and arrived at Walla Walla City at 3 PM and stop for the night-
Thursday Jan 2d 1879
The Stage left Walla Walla at 12:30 P.M. for the north, and at 4 P.M. was at Waitsburg, a little town on Touchet containing about 300 population - Here I leave the Stage and on Jan 3rd out on foot for Mr Bartges? 6 miles distant where I will remain for the present.
Monday Jan 6th 1879
Cold wintry weather, started for Pendelton.  Went to Waitsburg on Foot
Tuesday January 7th 1879
Took stage early for Walla Walla, arrived at 11 AM
Wednesday January 8th 1879
Took stage at 7.30 and was at Pendleton at 3 P.M.
Thursday January 9th 1879
Remained in Pendleton - Tomorrow is the day fixed? upon by the Law for the Execution of "White Owl" and "Quit it Tumps" two Umatilla Indians convicted of murder, committed during? the Bannock Indian raid of last year  These two Indians belonged to the Umatilla Agency, six miles above Pendleton, and went out on the war path and done a little killing on their own hook - One George Coggan being one of their victims, who was killed on the Reservation, and for whose murder they have been tried and convicted - The Indians from the Agency 6 miles above came in today

Bead work and Indian wampum- Their firebeads painted a bright yellow and faces and breasts of variegated colors- both wore mocasins neatly garnished with glistening bead work- White owl wore a spotted purple shirt with a handsome fur sash over his shoulder, while Quit it [unclear] was dressed in red flannel shirt and Leggins No one in Pendleton appeared more calm or self possessed than they-- Each on made their little speeches, interpretted into English by a half breed, who could not talk better English than the Indians--From what I could understand from their speeches and the interpretter, it seemed that the Indians claimed that they were right in all things, but that their guns might have been some times wrong
As the time was drawing near, the sheriff with his ready Kindness invited their Indian friends forward to the platform to bid them the final GoodBye- Hands were shaken and the parting salutations given without any appearance of emotion on the part of the doomed Indians, but a glistening eye and a quivering lip might have been noticed among their dusky friends, by any careful observer: A short Indian song in which all joined, of which no correct idea can be formed without being heard

 Time having arrived the Black Cap was drawn over their heads by the Sheriff, the ropes carefully adjusted about their necks when suddenly the two prisoners struck up one of those lively and animated songs, so peculiar to the tribe to which they belonged and continued to same in a sharp and hurried tone until the trap was sprung by the Sheriff. and it was a noticeable fact to all how suddenly the death song of White Owl and Quit it tumps was ended.  They fell about four feet. Quit it tumps died suddenly. but the body of White Owl seemed to

Friday January 10 1879
Black Friday - This is the day of Execution. Large crowds of people from all parts of the Country came in last night and during the forenoon today - A company of Volunteer Militia was on hand armed and equipped, and at 12.30 the two Cavalry Companies under Capt Jackson and Lieutenant Boutille? of Modoc fame came in and took position near the Jail - A high Jail Yard of plank has been constructed enclosing the Jail and Gallows, and within this enclosure about 75 whites and about a dozen Indians, chosen friends of the condemned, were permitted to enter. The writer admitted as a press Reporter - This was at 1.30 P.M. and everything being in readiness the two Indians were brought out White-Owl is a noble specimen of an Indian tall, straight. young and very white, with much more of an intelligent look than is generally found among Indians, And while not clothed with the dignity of Chief. yet undoubtedly would exercise much influence over the average Indian in time of war or peace, an Indian whom education and culture might have placed far above any of his tribe
Quit.it.tumps quite the reverse from White Owl is a fear specimen of a brutal savage, a full blooded Siwash - For the last 48 hours, in accordance with their barbarous Indian custom had entirely refused to partake of any kind of food except water and a few small fibers of dried meat - Neither hunger, nor the fear of death had made any impression upon them, and their step was light, quick and rapid from the cell to the Scaffold - There hair was combed, and braided and neatly ornamented with ribbons

Sunday January 12 1879                                     18
Remained in Walla Walla 
Monday January 13 1879
Stage to Waitsburg & footed it to Baetges

 Wednesday January 15 1879
  Friday January 17  1879
  Saturday 18 1879

Thursday Feb 13 1879

 Saturday Feb 15 1879

Thursday Feb 20 1879
Friday February 28 1879
George Baitges & I went to the timbered Mountains to my claim about 20 miles distant-- The weather was still cold and the ground frozen but the snow had pretty much wasted away upon the prairies.  but as we approached the timber on the Mts snow increased in depth and for a mile before reaching my place it was found to be 1 1/2 feet deep. so as to very much impede the progress of our riding animals and pack animals .  Arrived at my old log cabin at sundown and found several of the woodsmen who had claims around and near there, living therein, they had become attached to a large stone fireplace in the cabin & had left their own places when the deep snow had fallen to winter by this the best fire place in the woods

quiver for a moment or two, before life was quite extinct - The bodies were cut down at 2.45 P.M and were placed in the Black Coffins prepared for their reception and were delivered to their Indian friends who disposed of in accordance with their own Indian customs
They refused all offers of religious consolation, or any kind of interference on the part of the whites in regard to their future or the disposal of their bodies after death - Their religious doctrines is that of the "Dreamers" whose crede or belief comes very nearly if not quite up to the standard of our "Spiritualists" and they appear in all things to be equally as sincere in their belief, as any faithful members of our religious denominations can be
As soon as the bodies were placed in the Coffins, the friends of the dead Indians took possession of their bodies and placed them in wagons to be removed to be removed to their final resting place. All the Indians now struck up their funeral dirge and followed behind the wagons which gradually moved out of town
Another Indian named "Apps" a brother of Quit-it-tumps was tried as an accessory and convicted, and sentenced to be hung one week from today - Through the grates of the cell door he calmly witnessed the Execution today seemingly unmoved, but begged to be hung with his friends so he could die as easy as they. he seemed to dread being executed alone
Saturday January 11 1879
Still cold and the ground covered with snow. Yesterday the snow settled down on the roads and streets became very wet and sloppy - This morning it is cold & frozen Set out on the Stage and arrived at Walla Walla at noon or little after

19
Wednesday May 21 1879
Went to Wallula by train where we arrived at dark, went on board the Steamer to Sleep
Tuesday May 22 1879
Was at Cililo at about 10 A.M. - Freight and passenger transferred to train and we set out at 12 noon and was at the Dalles at 12?30 P.M. stopped at the Umatilla House as usual P.M. This was an unfortunate day for Dalles City - Fire broke out at about 3 1/2 P.M. in the Pioneer Hotel, centrally located and raged until dark, burning about seven blocks of buildings of the must business part of its city - The Umatilla house was burned with the balance and the passengers for below were forced to the boat for sleeping accommodations 
Thursday May 23 1879
Set out a while after daylight and reached Portland at 5 PM
Friday May 24 1879
By Rail Road train I reached Roseburg at 7 PM where I remained until
Monday June 2 1879
When I set out on my return to the Upper Country reaching Portland by R.R. at 5 P.M.
Tuesday June 3d 1879
Went on board the Steamer "Wide West" for the Cascades. Train to the Upper Cascades - Steamer R.R. Thompson for the Dalles and Train for Cililo where we arrived at sundown and went on board the "Harvest Queen" for Wallula
Wednesday June 4 1879
Arrived at Wallula at dark, Western Hotel

Saturday March 1st 1879
Barges returned home today with the horses
Tuesday March 18 1879
Went to Dayton on Foot 12 miles
Wednesday March 19 1879
Went to Bartges' on foot 8 miles
Saturday March 25 1879
Tuesday March 26 1879
Bartges went to the Mountain to take me back home with horses and hack the snow is soft and about a foot deep in the thick timber, but very wet underneath - Left hack 1/2 mile from Cabin and took the horses there for the night
Wednesday March 27 1879
Bartges returned home today, and I engaged a Mr Newlin? with a hand unclear to aid me to bring my little supplies from the place where we left the Hack wagon last night
May 20 1879
Having returned to Bartges' and being required to return to Douglas County Oregon I set out - in Mr B' Hack and after reaching a point about half way to Walla Walla we were overtaken by a team going into Town and I took passage upon that B retuned home - I was in Walla Walla at noon

20
Tuesday July 1 1879
The weather is exceedingly hot - I am at the Stine House, the place I usually stop when at Walla Walla, and it is said to be the only First class Hotel in the city - Delayed today on business with Mr Sturgess & Judge Shopstein. 
Wednesday July 2 1879
Still warm - Still delayed by some unsettled business - At 10.30 A.M. Mrs Agnes E. Daniels came on the Stage from Waitsburg. She was going on a visit to her mothers near relations at LaGrand in Union Co Oregon and about 100 miles on my direct route - As a friend of hers and since her birth I felt glad of an opportunity to assist her with her trunk and other baggage, also with her boy who was an invalid She was assigned to room 42 opposite the Main Parlor door on the second floor
Thursday July 3d 1879
Mrs Daniels, myself and one other passenger set out on the Stage at 7 AM for Pendleton, she being quite unwell. we arrived at Pendleton several hours before night and put up at the "Bon Ton" Hotel where the stage stopped My room on lower floor next to the Kitchen Mrs D' Room, was the Parlor
Friday July 4 1879
Stage for Lagrand left at 2:30 A.M. and had 13 passengers on board, we took our breakfast, a poor one, at the foot of the Blue Mts. - Then began the long ascent entering the timber, passing "Meachams" formerly know as "Lees Encampment" so on & arrived in Grand Round Vally at 3 PM and was at Lagrand at 4 P.M. - I hired a Buggy and took Mrs Daniels to Mr Gouldsberrys her uncles, about 10 miles distant - Here she expects

Thursday June 5 1879
Went on Train reached Walla Walla at 11 A.M. took stage for Waitsburg & footed it to Bartges'
Friday June 6 1879
Saturday June 7 1879
Bartges took Hack and went with me to the Cabin in the timbered Mountains above Dayton
Sunday June 8 1879
F.M. Newlin? returned with us and we went to Walla Walla to make proof on a Claim of land
Monday June 9 1879
Proved up on claim. Newlin & Bartges were witnesses. Cash unclear No 1002 - Com H. 1182
Sunday June 29 1879
Being ready to start to the Yellowstone country in Montana, and desirous to go as far as Waitsburg this evening Mr B. with his horses and Hack took me that far and returned home
Monday June 30 1879
St out on the stage for Walla Walla and arrived there at about half past 10 Made a Will which was witnessed by Mr A. Small - J.C. Isacs and Lane 6, Gilliam. and sent the same to George H. Bartges by Express to be by him sent to the County Judge of Douglas County Oregon, in case death should occur
Room No 7 in third story

21
Thursday July 10 1879
Left Lagrand for the Yellowstone country by the way of Boise. the Utah Northern - Virginia City & c - Follow up the vally along and near the foot hills about 6 miles. Thence up the Canyon of Ladd Creek to the right through open pine woods about 6 miles further to a low divide between Grand Round River on the West and Powder River on the East, thence over an undulating plain for about 10 miles and coming to a little stream called Clover Creek where good water and grass appeared I camped at 2 PM. having travelled about 22 miles - Day hot This stream is about 10 feet wide. has in the high mountains a few miles to the S.W. and empties into North Powder River a few miles below - A few miles S.W. arises quite abruptly the Powder River Mts, with numerous conical peaks still covered with snow, and at and about which much mining has been and still is being carried on - Distance 20 miles
Friday July 11 1879
Set out early and at about one mile crossed the North Powder River of about 60 feet in width with the usual willow skirting along its banks, and struck off over the bitter sage bush plains and at 4 miles cross the Main Powder River on a Toll Bridge. this is about the same size of North Powder, has a swift current and flows a strong volume of muddy water from the many mining camps above - Following along the East side of the River, some distance back therefrom for about 16 miles and enter Baker City the County seat of Baker County; a small mining town, of two or three hundred inhabitants Passing through the town we soon leave

remain a few days on a visit - It was cold today, and rained a portion of the time while in the mountains
Saturday July 5 1879
I had intended to go to Boise City by stage and buy my riding horse and pack horse there and my little outfit as well, but a man from Boise advises me to buy my horses here as they can be purchased here much cheaper - So I set about looking for horses - Returned to Lagrand early in the forenoon with my livery team, saw several horses for sale but did not quite like the price 
Sunday July 6 1879
Went over to Mr Goldsberrys, and saw several horses he had mentioned to me and bought a riding horse saddle and right? of one Mr Tom Childess
Monday July 7 
Again returned to Lagrand, and directed Mr Gouldsberry to buy a certain grey mare we had seen, but whose owner was not at home, leaving the money with him to pay for it
Tuesday July 8 1879
Returned to Gouldsberrys and he had bought me a very good horse for $40 - but not the one I had wished him to buy - However I took the two and am now ready to go
Wednesday, July 9 1879
Reached Lagrand early in the day and completed my outfit, it taking longer and being more bother to find and buy a packsaddle than all else

about 3 miles we camp for the night on the River bank - The country appears dry and very much burnt up - a few feeble attempts at farming may be seen, but it appears necessary to irrigate to raise any kind of grain crops - Grain is light and rather light. Burnt River runs through a Canyon with high and abrupt mountains bording? upon it with bold escarpments of basalt facing the River at nearly every turn - mining seems to have been done all along the river. and old and abandoned mining camps can be seen at short intervals
We are now in Idaho Territory, the River being the line separating this Territory from Oregon - Mosquitoes are bad along the River, and we are pestered with them in camp today - Distance 23 miles. The water of the River is warm & alkaline
Monday July 14th 1879 Was under way at sunrise - Follow up River 2 miles along a narrow bottom, and then enter upon an extensive unknown plain of several miles in width and at 14 miles come with Weiser River 30 yds wide running West into the Snake River, a short distance away. Continued on 12 miles further and came upon a bend of Snake River. no grass. day hot. water poor. Rested two hours and again set out through the better unknown - same plains and at 8 miles crossed the Payette River a brisk stream 100 yds wide running into the Snake River to the right: over which a Ferry is kept - Passing the stream one half mile and camp. grass poor. scarcely any at all Large numbers of Rabbits appear and several hundred can be counted within a radius of

the main River and follow up a small muddy alkali branch to the left and at about 3 miles camp at 1 P.M. - The day has been cool - The camp ground poor - grass scant and water alkolied & muddy - a thick growth of sage brush everywhere, and a few rabbits and prairie chickens are the only game Distance 23 miles
Saturday July 12 1879
Out at daylight hunting after my horses found them back at Baker City, therefore did not get away from Camp until 9 A.M. Proceed up the small branch two or three miles and cross over a divide in the low hills to a stream running Easterly into Burnt River - Follow this down some distance and then cross over a hill to the left and down a Canyon to Burnt River which I follow down about 3 miles, and seeing good grass on the opposite side, I cross over and Camp for the night having come 28 miles Burnt River is about 25 yds wide. the usual small shrubbery along its banks and muddy turbid water in its bed A few chickens sage hens and rabbits abound, and two unclear playfully approaching were both killed at one shot - Distance 28 m
Sunday July 13 1879
An early start soon brought me to a Toll Gate - Continuing on crossing the River 5 times and at 16 miles bear off to the left and by an easy ascent we are soon at a grassy summit and have Snake River in full view about 2 1/2 miles ahead by an easy descent - Soon after reach the Ferry and cross over the River (100 yds wide) to the opposite side where we find the road to follow up stream to the right and falling up

here a few years ago by an energetic Boiseite upon the promise that a law should be framed for their protection, which was accordingly done. Boise City was settled during the great mining excitement of 1862&3. upon a level sage plain as the North side of the Boise River. nicely lain out & looks like a thrifty locality. Supplies are furnished here from Kelton as the C.P.R.R. by teams a distance of about 300 miles. The stages from Salt Lake, Nevada, Idaho & Oregon, make this a central point, and here is where the miners of a large District of Country obtain their supplies. A Military Post on the northern outskirts of town adds to its importance and beauty. Distance 20 miles.
Thursday July 17 - 1879 
Remained at Boise, answering letters etc
Friday July 18 - 1879
Set out this morning Eastward upon the Stage road leading towards Salt Lake - passing along through the Sage valley about 8 miles to where the same terminates in a Canyon. Follow up the Canyon 2 miles and the road crosses over to the South side on a Toll Bridge. The River is about 75 yds wide, muddy water and swift current. Leave the River at this point and follow more southerly up a willow brand about 6 miles, thence over a summit about 2 miles and camp in a willow gulch with a few springs of poor water just above the road. Distance traveled 16 miles. Rabbits. Sage. hens & chickens seem to abound. Black crickets are found here in immense numbers. So much so that it appears impossible to do anything, move or step without coming in contact with them by hundreds. Distance 18 miles.

one quarter of a mile. They live in the sage brush like the Jack ass Rabbits, but are a little smaller than those animals, have a black tail about 3 inches long, and when they stop they of stand straight up, with ears erect and resemble a small deer. Whole distance today 34 miles. Bitter sage, all the way
Tuesday July 15 1879 
Horses were browsing around in the sage brush this morning, and look thin and gaunt. Follow up the River (Payette) about 12 miles bearing gradually to the right, when we ascend the hills and leave sight of the River entirely. Travelling 10 miles over the hills and we descend gradually to the Stage Station on what is called Willow Creek. a dry stream with a narrow border of Willow brush on its banks. This is 20 miles from Boise City and I stop for the night at the house and feed my horses in the stage Barn. Distance 22 miles.
Wednesday July 16 1879
Day fearfully hot. Travelled about 3 miles over the bitter sage hills and coming to a summit have the Boise River valley of many miles in extent with its belt of green timber along the River, before you, running a course nearly East and West through the Center. The descent from the hills is easy and short when we enter upon the Broad sage valley a few farms along at intervals, crossing, irrigating ditches here and there, and at 20 miles arrive at Boise City the Capitol of the Territory containing a population of 2000. Along the valley, heard at short intervals the familiar sound of the old fashioned "Bob White" quail of the Northern states, which abound in Considerable numbers in Boise Valley. Having been brought

Monday July 21 1879
Set out early, in advance of the Emigrant family, at about 3 miles enter upon "Big Camas prarie" a level tract of fine looking valley land about 20 miles N & S by 49 E & W. The road following along on the north side of this vally crossing brisk little streams of water coming from the Mountains on the left and skirted with willows wending their way to the Malade River in the south part of the valley. We made camp on one of these streams at about 3 oclock P.M. and were pestered almost to death by the myriad of crickets upon the surface of the ground all over this portion of the valley. The crickets were large black fellows an inch and a half in length by a half inch in diameter. They covered the ground in the evening two or three deep so that we found it impossible to make down our blankets without crushing them by hundreds. They eat holes in our blankets, eat up our sacks and our clothes did not escape. When going to bed we found them in astonishing numbers in our blankets and when we at last becoming exhausted in waiting and fighting the hateful black pests we concluded to trust no Providence and the merciful black crickets and got into bed and covered up: As we lay down solid and quick, the mashing of crickets in our blankets sounded very much as if we had fell full length in a oblong box of eggs. No one could sleep much of course. Their bite upon your fingers, toes, ears and other places was similar to the bite of a mouse and equally as sharp and painful. Falling into a drowsy condition toward morning, a huge cricket taking advantage of the situation, took position on my chin, and singling out the tenderest spot on my lower lip, already raw and much swollen from the effects of Alkali water. perhaps

Saturday July 19 - 1879 Travel 12 miles over hilly ground and then leave the Stage road and take what is called the Mountain Cattle Trail to the left leaving the Stage road & entering upon the old Emigrant road via Fort Hall, which road has been travelled a little with wagons never every year for a third of a century, unclear is not a very general thoroughfare - 
We travel 18 mile over a rough, rocky & hilly country, with water at intervals and camp by a large springy side hill on the right, where a portion of the side hill has slid down with slight unclear of water oozing out at numerous places. For up on the side hill, near the top of the slide I obtained very good cool water by scooping out the mud and making a little reservoir: Around this camp, Greaking? asp, bushes abound, grass poor, but good grass was found on the hill about a mile back. Distance 30 miles
Sunday July 20 1879
Travelled over ground composed of hills, valleys and table lands, passing several bands of cattle going to Cheyenne and the Larimie plains. Camped on a small brand of good water. Met several Emigrant trains today on their way to Eastern Oregon and Washington Territorys. They had com in from the border states by the way of Fort Hall. The afternoon was blustering, very windy & dusty indeed, and towards evening heavy thunder and lightning. Passed a family with a wagon and 40 head of loose horses driven by a woman today and this evening late they came in and camped by me. they were from Colfax in Eastern W. I. and going to Bozeman M. I. certainly a round about road. Distance 25 miles

not excused by the Black fellows where they marshalled their forces and charged so irresistibly upon us in our blankets last night = 22 miles
Wednesday July 23rd 1879 
Crossed the Big Wood River this morning and found the same deep and about 50 yds wide, running through a large land & gravelly bar in several channels. Follow down the Sage valley about 10 miles where we leave the River and bear off to the left and enter hilly land again, and at 5 miles cross "Little Wood River" a stream, tributary to "Big Wood River", also rapid, with Cottonwood along its banks, runs south and abounds in Trout. Crossing this stream we travel over rough hilly ground about 15 miles and camp in a deep little valley between high hills at a spring of cold water where one found a lot of miners encamped, also two or three wagons, and a band of cattle. 30 miles
Thursday July 24 1879
I was directed by the prospectors at camp to take a trail turning off about one mile ahead and bear off over the hills to the left and thus save 12 miles in distance. I found the trail as directed and started up a ravine and in a mile or two cam to the foot of a high summit, the trail leading over the same. At the top of this summit we saw four black tail deer, far down a ravine and I fired four shots at them, as they trotted off and finally has the satisfaction of seeing one of their number, waver, stagger, swing out of the land and fall, the others made off and appeared unhurt. We now have fresh meat for several days. Descending down a steep ravine of about 1 1/2 miles we are at a little creek coming in from the left and joining the wagon road at this place again. we become

in as careful a manner as possible, siezed the lower lip and with a forcible and painful effort brought me to my feet standing in a second of time. The lip bled for some time and I felt the effects of the bit for many days afterwards. Distance 30 miles
Tuesday July 22nd 1879
Started before daylight to get away from the abominable crickets, and at about 12 miles left the Camas Valley and entered upon hilly land, the ground covered with lava?, and following over this kind of country 10 miles we descend gradually to "Big Wood" river, a clear stream of rapid water running through a level sage vally of three or 4 miles wide. the stream makes it way south to the Malade River a tributary of the Snake River. Cotton. now timber abounds along the stream. Game such as Rabbits, chickens, sagehens and sandhill cranes abounds. and no stream on the continen furnishes trout in greater profusion than Wood River and its tributaries. 
Trout weighing from 2 to 5 pounds could be caught with a hook & line at the rate of a couple of dozen every half hour. An Emigrant wagon from Kansas came in and camped near where I had just caught 15 trout. I took away 5 of the number and gave the remainder to the western bound traveller, who weight the fish and found them to weigh 28 pounds. Crickets was the favorite bait for trout and while they were not numerous at this point yet a few could be easily caught and it afforded great pleasure and much satisfaction to gather up the member of the large family of our black persecutors of last night and cast them upon the sparkling clear waters of the stream, and see the myriads of trout rush upon them, with an energy and determination

26
Saturday July 26 1879
Follow down and around on the right hand side of the Sink of Little Lost River, and over the same kind Sage plains, passing a spring branch at 6 miles, and at a distance of 16 miles further arrive at and cross Birch Creek a rapid stream of 20 feet wide running south, no grass, but a small growth of timber on its banks. On the East side of this Creek is a stage road running from the Rail Road to points north in Montana - There being no good Grass here, we pursued a Course by a poor road East across the same Kind of level sage lands and camp on a small spring branch which sinks in the plain a little below - Distance 35 miles 
Sunday July 27 1879
An early start this morning, and at two miles came to a deep little channel of water and 10 miles farther coming to "Medicine Lodge Creek" we concluded to camp at 10 A.M. This stream is about 20 feet wide, rapid contains trout. and a narrow strip of thick woodland along its banks - Distance 12 miles
Monday July 28 1879
Found Antelope and sand hill cranes at our yesterdays camp, and also quite an abundance of mountain Trout - Set out this morning at 6 oclock easterly on an old road not travelled for a year or two and at 10 miles through the sage brush hills were pleased to come in sight of the great overland wagon road from Montana to  Salt-Lake and here along this road and near were the Grades and track layers of the Utah Northern Rail Road extending their work north from this

satisfied we had actually saved the distance warned. Following over hilly ground along the foot of the mountains on the left, and the most vast and extensive Lava beds anywhere to be found on the plains, immediately to the right of us, for about 10 miles when we pass three small muddy streams with scarcely water enough for animals. Thence 25 miles over a Desert Sage plain without grass or water and reach "Lost River" and camp late. This stream is deep, about 30 yds wide flows south and sinks in the vicinity of three lone and prominent Buttes about 30 miles off. apparently rising directly out of the level ground. 
At this place we find a trading post and a very plainly travelled wagon road running from the terminus of the Utah Northern R. R. and a new mining District recently opened up to the northern? and in the mountains on the extreme head of Salmon River, and many teams came in from each way and camped here tonight. This is the first house we have seen since leaving the Boise & Salt Lake Stage Road on the 19~ a distance of 175 miles = Distance today 40 miles
Friday July 25 1879
Horses fared poor last night. Alkali Sage plains, but no grass. This morning we were joined by three Californians all going to Virginia City, making a respectable ?ith party of 8 in all. Our course was Easterly over a level sage plain of dust to "Little Lost River", a stream about 10 yds wide running South sinking in a little pond about one half mile below. Camped here for the night. Distance 25 miles.

Wednesday July 30 ~1879
Country rough and hilly today. Water at short intervals. good grass everywhere since striking the main unclear and road. Camped on a small spring branch in a deep gorge where evergreen trees seem to be plenty on the tops of the mountains. Game abounds in limited quantities at and around this place = Distance 20m
Thursday July 31 1879
Set out at the normal hour, passing? out of the canyon and at two miles come to the Black tailed Deer Creek, a stream of 20 feet wide flowing west to the Jefferson. Continuing over hilly ground, and camp at noon on the Stinking water a tributary of the Jefferson, running through a level plain with unclear bluffs a short distance back, timber along the banks. water poor. and derives its name from the Indian tradition of the hard winter of 40 years ago, in which the snow came very deep and cold winter continued for a long time and the vast herds of Buffalo that roamed the Country at will during those days made their way into this pretty little and were overwhelmed with the cold and fury of the storms and perished in such astonishing numbers along the creek and in the creek that when spring set in no living animals were left and the stink from the decaying carcasses rendered the atmosphere of this whole region of country so oppressive and the water of the stream became so tinctured with the odious deposits that for many years they could not drink it at all. Hence they called it in their crude Indian dialect "Stinking water" a name pretty generally adopted by the whites

the present northern terminus - Leaving this point at noon we turned our horses head northward and by a big wagon road with telegraph poles at one side and the Rail Road graders on the other. the whole line appeared very much more animated than any part of the road we had passed over. A few miles north and we enter the little valley of a Creek & follow up the same, passing camp after camp of the Rail Road laborers and coming to a find branch of the purest kind of cold water we encamped among the willows? for the night at a point 300 miles north of the C.P.R.R. and about 90 miles south of Virginia City 20 miles
Tuesday July 29 ~1879
The stream upon which we encamped last night is called Beaver Creek, has a narrow valley and plenty of willow brush along the creek banks, and at about 5 miles we pass the last of the working camps and at 15 miles cross the Summit of the Rocky Mts which is a low hilly gap, and here the Rail Road Engineers are at work fixing the grade across the great backbone of the Continent went from the west side to the east side. the general course of the Summit being South East. Five miles from the summit come to the forks of the major Road called the Junction. Follow the right hand and Telegraph Pole road 4 mile through hills and camp on the Jefferson a stream 20 feet wide running west through quite a pretty valley and afterwards swinging around north and forming one of the three forks of the Missouri Distance 29 miles

angling across the prairie towards the road we came to a pond? of one or two hundred yards in extent and in going around to the right upon a well beaten cattle trail, the same was found to be shaky and several of our animals mired down and wallowed and floundered in the soft mud or quagmire, which seemed to be fresh covered with a this turf of grass. I was riding in the lead and looking back to see the cause of the commotion among the horses. My own riding animal sunk suddenly down and a pack animal near him fell and commenced floundering. I jumped off my horse and he at once made a spring for the Pack animal, climbed up on to him, stamping him down almost out of sight, and then made a desperate lunge for dry ground which he reached in safety. Out stock was soon extricated, the mud cleaned off the packs as much as possible where we packed up again and set out upon the road which led down the stinking water about 8 miles, thence leaning off to the right we enter low hills and camp on a small branch Distance 10 miles.
Saturday August 2nd 1879,
Washed all our muddy blankets and things yesterday afternoon and being in no hurry today we did not leave camp until about 9 oclock A.M. The Road led over hills and at 7 miles we descend into Alder Gulch, which we follow up stream to the right about one mile, when we turn around a point of a hill and find ourselves entering Virginia City the former Capitol of Montana built upon the North side of Alder Gulch and at the Junction of Alder Gulch and Daylight Gulch Contains about 1000 population --

although the Legislature of Montana at one time changed the name from Stinking water to "Ruby River" yet no one has ever be found to call it by its new found legal name. Like an early Legislature in Oregon, who were to delicate and modest to acknowledge that one of their principal Rivers was named Rogue River, endeavored to Legislate the obnoxious name out of existence, and therefore named the objectionable stream "Isold" River, but the name has never been pronounced aloud since that time. Along the Stinking water may be seen thousands of old and bleaching Buffalo skulls which appear to have been bleaching in the Rocky Mountain air for a period of 40 or 50 years. giving some evidence of the truth of the hard winter and the great destruction of Buffalo at the time mentioned - and further more the oldest Indians & half breeds of the country say that no Buffalo have existed in the vicinity for about 40 years. Distance 20 miles
Friday Aug 1 1879
A band of wild horses came along last night and all of our horses went off with them. We found them about 3 miles away on the ranges up the River towards the foot of the Mountains. We could not get nearer than 1/2 mile to the band, and as they would run away ours would trot along after them. We could not catch any of them and returned to the nearest house on the Creek and got some riding animals, went after them and only caught our own by corralling the whole band. We packed up and set out in the afternoon and about a half mile from camp

Monday August 4 ~1879
Set out with a little party of men, curiosity hunters, for the celebrated Geysers situated on the Fire Hole River a tributary of the Madison and in the great national Park. Passing out of town we bear off South Easterly over a range of bold hills about 10 miles to the Madison River, which heads in the Yellowstone Mts runs N. W. and constitutes one of the Three forks of the Missouri River. The Madison Valley is noted for its beauty is several miles wide, often rising in benches or tables one above the other, covered with fine bunch grass all over it with some of it rocky and gravelly, but much of it composed of good farm lands. We followed up the West bank or right hand side about 5 miles and camped on a little branch of clear water about 8 feet wide Distance 13 miles
Tuesday August 5 ~1879
Set out pretty early, at 2 miles cross a creek about 15 feet wide. rapid and good water This is called Spring Creek - at 3 miles further cross Wigwam Creek 200 feet wide - and at 10 oclock A. M. we cross Ruby Creek about 10 feet wide. and at 1/2 mile further, finding no road or trail we forded the Madison 50 yds wide. swift & rocky bottom. to the east side Ascending to the bench lands a little back from the river, and enter upon a trail which leads to the Virginia City & National Park Wagon road. a little back from the River, but not travelled very much -- Following up and cross one stream from the left of 15 feet wide, and soon camp on the river bank there good grass & water - Distance 21 miles

Virginia City was built up under a tremendous mining excitement which started in 1863 and Alder Gulch upon which the city is built proved to be and still is one of the richest mining camps any where forever in the Great North West. The place is surrounded by high bold hills and as you approach the high lands south of town you have a fine view of all the surroundings above and below beyond and before, but the formation of the hills are such that no part of the town is visible until you enter the margin of the busy city itself. Distance 7 miles
Sunday August 3rd 1879
Stayed in town, answered letters and so on --

stream of 20 feet wide, thence turn directly to the left up the valley of said stream north easterly into the mountains with timber & praries alternating and at about 6 miles again stand upon the (timbered) summit of the Rocky Mountains and can overlook the Fire hole basin and the Upper Madison Valley ahead = From the summit we follow down Beaver Dam Creek a small stream full of Beaver dams. to the level valley about 3 miles from the summit - Here the road bears off more to the right and at about 4 miles come to the South Fork of the Madison which we cross and camp on the opposite side of 11 AM - This stream is rapid and about 40 yds wide, with a swampy or mrshy margin with Deer, Elk, Antelope, geese, ducks, and fish in great abundance - A vast deal of game was killed and large quantities of fish were caught and as usual under such circumstances allowed to go to waste - 16 miles
Friday August 8 ~1879
Lay in camp - Killed game, and caught fish
Saturday August 9 ~1879
Set out at about 8 oclock, and at about 8 miles struck the Fire hole River, the middle bank of the three Forks of the Madison Follow along, mostly through timber, near the RIver for seven or eight miles further and turn to the right up and enter the Fire Hole Canyon - The stream is about 40 yds wide, which is crossed 5 times when we arrive at Gibbons Fork, an easterly branch and which we cross about 1/4 mile above the junction - The road here follows through a range of timbered hills, entirely out of sight of the River, for a distance of about 8 miles when

Wednesday August 6 ~1879
This morning set out, crossing two rapid little streams and at 6 miles cross over the Madison by a rough rocky ford to the South bank, & follow up and along the river about 8 miles further where the road leaves the River abruptly and turns square off to the right & follows for 10 miles up a dry valley, with high mts on each side a few miles off, to the grassy summit of the Rocky Mountains, which has the appearance of being several thousand feet lower than the mountains on either side, a mile away from you - From this summit you can look forward? and see Henry Lake about 4 miles distant a magnificent sheet of water about 3 miles by four, with swamp and marshy surroundings, a favorite place for water fowls, and Geese, ducks, swans, and all kinds of waders inhabit this lake and raise their young around its brushy and marshy border - A few bear & deet are occasionally seen around the Lake and Beaver Cuttings are plenty - A portion of the margin is swampy, and often it is difficult to approach to the margin of the Lake we camped on the East side on a brisk little stream of Cold water: Game plenty today among other Animals the writer killed a Wolverine, thinking at first it was a Young Bear. A sand hill crane and a fen smaller birds were brought in and everything seems to be flourishing in camp Distance 24 miles
Thursday August 7 ~1879
The road followed down the left hand or east side of the lake through a fine bunch grass plain for about 3 miles when we cross a brisk

the road descends from the hilly ground to the Fire hole river where we camp for the night, on a sandy black pine level Deer. geese. Ducks. & other game -- Distance 24 miles
Sunday August 10
At two miles we cross the East Fork of the Fire Hole River 20 yds wide & being now fairly in the Lower Geyser basin, we camp for the day & turn our horses out - Distance 2 miles
Monday August 11 1879
Having visited all the great natural curiosities of the Lower Basin, we set out at noon for the Upper Basin, nine miles distant - Our course was nearly South across a low section of swampy land for about 3 miles when we enter timbered lands along the river bank - Reach upper Baisn at 3 P.M. Distance 9 miles
Tuesday Aug 12 1879
Remained and more thoroughly explored the great curiosities of the Upper Geyser Basin - For more full particulars and descriptions, see printed descriptions -
Newspaper clipping "THE MADISONIAN Saturday, August 9, 1879. THOS. DEYARMON, Editor and Propriator THOS BAKER, . . . Associate. Capt. L. L. Williams, an old Oregonian and mountaineer, was in the city the first of the week, en route to the Geysers with a small party of wonder-seekers. The Captain passed over this country from Fort Benton to Fort Hall, in 1849, at which time he was in the employ of the Fur Company. He is a rough looking old chap, who bears the marks of many years of frontier life, and looks good for many more, yet."

Friday August 15 1879
Course N.W. over fine grass valley land, along and near the foot hills on the right, and at about 6 miles we came upon the East bank of the Madison River, where the valley narrows and turns to the right, where we follow for about 5 miles and camp near the lower extremity of the valley land - Saw many antelope - ducks & geese today - Fired away a vast deal of ammunition as usual and consequently had lots of game we throw away. At camp we noticed a little flock of seven swan, a fire was opened upon and four out of the seven were killed. I had the good fortune to kill two at one shot Distance 10 miles
Saturday August 16~1879
Down the River one half mile and cross a brisk stream of 30 feet wide and enter upon narrow timbered limits, the mountains on each side being high and precipitous - Follow this down about 10 miles emerge from the timberland gorge into the Madison Valley below where we soon cross the River to the opposite side and a short distance below come to the wagon Road, which is followed down to the Ford where we cross over and camp on a brisk stream 20 feet wide about one mile beyond - Distance 25 miles
Sunday August 17 ~1879
Down the River two miles. stream 20 feet wide 4 miles further Stream 20 feet - at 4 miles from this cross the Madison to the West or South side - 1/2 mile further cross Ruby Creek 15 feet wide - 12 mile further

Wednesday Morning Aug, 13 1879
Having visited all the great shouting Geysers of the Basin and other curiosities of the Park, we set out today on our return. We bid Good Bye to Isen? Buckner & his party of 6 tourists from Ohio and quite an array of other visitors, and turned our horses heads down river and was soon at the Lower Geyser Basin Proceeded down and camped on the East fork of Gibbons Fork of the Fire Hole River Distance 20 miles -
Thursday August 14 ~1879
Followed down river 6 miles to the mouth of the Fire Hole Canyon, and here we take a blind trail leading to the right and crossing the River. we follow down through thick timber, much obstructed with fallen black pine, travelled all day but had no trail after the first two or three miles and finally camped a little before night on a tributary of the East Fork of Madison - Saw considerable game today - Our design has been to pass down this way and by a poor trail through the Upper Madison Canyon as it is called into the valley below and soar? the long and circuitous route by Henry Lake - We crossed two streams today coming in from the north, each of about 20 feet wide. water warmish After we had been in camp a short time we saw a couple of horsemen coming up the valley with a few loose animals - They proved to be whitemen, and don't know their destination. They camped by us and their dog eat up all our meat or else it was stolen during the night - Distance 22 miles

34

cross Wigwam Creek 20 feet wide and at 1 mile further camp on Spring Creek, about 20 feet wide - Distance 24 miles
