36
down the valley, nearing the Jefferson all the time - Passing near the mouth of the Big Hole River, the main western branch of the Jefferson, recently become quite noted as the Battle Ground between Gen Gibbon and Chief Josephs Band of renegade Nez Perces in 1877 - The road gradually neared the Jefferson, and at noon came to the Bridge across that stream which is about 75 yds wide, course N.E. - After crossing, the road keeps along on the opposite side through extending plains, gradually leaving the River farther to the right, where at 3 P.M. I camped on a small branch coming in from the west
The three forks, Jefferson, Madison and Gallatin, forming a Junction at or near the same place a out 40 miles below here constitute the Missouri River - They are historical from the fact that they were discovered and named by the great Explorers Lewis & Clark on their great Expedition across the Continent in 1803-6 Those intrepid explorers were instructed by the Jefferson Administration to ascend the Missouri River to its sourse. thence cross the Rocky Mountains, and explore the then unknown Columbia from its sourse to its mouth The course of the Missouri was all favorable until they reached a point near where Ft Burton now is when the River made an abrupt trending to the Southwest: following South the Explorers were thrown off from their Western Course, and were soon after further disappointed to see bear more

Monday August 18 1879
We went up Spring Creek this morning about 2 miles, and struck a poor Wagon Road bearing to the right over the hills, by a cluster of small Lakes or ponds. thence to Virginia City where we all arrived at noon - Distance 15 miles
Tuesday August 19 1879
This morning, in response to numerous letter read from Oregon and Washington Territory, I set out on my return - Finding the route by Snake River so long and tedious. I have thought to return by one of the more northern routes, So I set out on the road for Helena about 120 miles north of here - The road is down the Alder Gulch about 6 miles to where it enters the Stinking Water Valley, thence swing around to the right, more northerly and follow the valley about 18 miles, to the little Town of Sheridan - passing which we camp on small creek to the right of the road about 4 miles from town Have fine view of Stinking Water Valley and also its Junction with the Jefferson, and the handsome looking valley of that stream extending of South for many miles - Farmers are settled all along the route today but grain, although green is a pretty good crop generally. Irrigation is required in all cases where farming is done - Distance 22 miles
Wednesday August 20 1879
Grass was poor upon the range last night and I found that my horses were about two miles off. Got them up and set out

37
Thursday August 21 1879
Course was northward up a small Creek valley for 15 miles, thence 6 miles over hilly ground and camped on the head of a small branch in a quaking ash grove - Deer quite numerous and one was killed from camp - Distance 21 miles
Friday August 22d 1879
Broken hills and pretty  little valleys alternating all day - At 20 miles pass through the small village of Jefferson, a mining town and follow down a branch and camp two miles beyond
Hill tops today all generally covered with pine & fir timber - Distance 22 miles
Saturday August 23d 1879.
Mining grounds all day. Come out into the level plains East of Helena when the road swings around to the left more westerly and at 11 A.M. am in Helena the Capital of the Territory - A mining town situated at the foot hills on the South, with fine level plains, E. W. & South of it - has 4000 Inhabitants, and is by far the most prosperous town in Montana - Distance 20 miles
Sunday Aug 24~ 1879
Set out after breakfast upon the Road west for Missoula, passed up the Ten Mile valley and over the Tocky Mountains by what is known as the Frenchwomans road, and camp at the foot of the mountain on a small branch running west into Little Blackfoot a tributary of Clarks Fork of Columbia Distance 21 miles
Monday August 25 1879
Heavy frost last night - Froze ice in camp kettle so that could not break it with the hand

more easterly, until it assumed a course nearly South Easterly and parallel with the summit ridge of the Rocky Mts which was only a few miles to the westernward - True to their Instructions they traced the stream South East directly out of the course they desired to go, when by its tortuous windings it brought them to a point where three forks of the same size all united at one point - Not desiring to go any further S.E. which was directly out of their  Course, for the mouth of the Columbia and yet wishing to carry out their Instructions to the letter, by tracing the Missouri to its sourse, They hit upon the ingenious idea of naming each of the three forks by a separate name, and calling that the sourse or head of the Missouri - And to pacify the heads of the Departments, they named the Western one of the three the Jefferson, and the middle the Madison and the more Eastern the Gallatin, after the President and his favorite legal advisors Having reached the Sourse of the Great Missouri, they now retraced their steps northwest? past the place where Helena the Capital now is and at a point on the river below they struck off westward, over the Great Rocky Mts and down the Clarks fork to the Columbia for the sea
Distance today 24 miles

38
I packed up and set out, but it soon commenced raining and continued until after I reach Missoula Distance 18 miles
Friday Aug 29 1879
Having concluded to return to my present home 25 miles South of Walla Walla in W.T. by the La La Fork Trail over the Bitter root Mts, I set out at about 8 this morning and crossing the Missoula on a bridge, starting from the foot of and of the Streets, over an Island which divides the river into two channels, and strike off across a level plain and at 4 miles have Fort Missoula about 1/2 mile to the right upon the bank of Bitter Root River Thence up Bitter Root Vally about 4 or 5 miles further and ford the stream over to the West side - The stream is clear, brisk and has fine pebbly bottom - Following up about 4 miles on the west side through farm lands I find myself at the mouth of the Lo Lo Creek of about 30 yds wide a tributary of Bitter Root - The old Indian trail called the Lo Lo Fork trail follows up this stream to near its source, thence over the mountains and down the Clear Water valley to Lewiston - This trail has been travelled by the Indians from time immemorial and was made more noted from the fact that Chief Joseph and his little band of renegade Nez Perces in 1877, escaped from their own Country on the Snake and Clearwater Rivers over the mountains to Montana where paused by Gen Howard of the U.S.A I followed up this creek by a good trail through open timbered land 6 miles and camped - Distance 20 miles

Set out and soon came to Little Black Foot and follow it down crossing it two or more times and Camp at the mouth of Deer Lodge Creek - Distance 25 miles
Tuesday Aug 26 1879
Down the River by the usual road 20 miles to New Chicago of about a Dozen houses, thru? 1/2 Junction to Flint Creek, passing the valley of said Creek and ascend the Flint Creek hills and camp at the springs on unclear - 28miles
Wednesday August 27 1879
Descend from this camp and follow down a little branch to the Little Black Foot again and at 14 miles come to Toll Bridge where we cross to the North side, thence down by the usual road fording the same 4 times and camp at 3 P.M. at a small prarie on right hand side of road, 18 miles above Missoula Distance 32 miles
Thursday August 28 1879
Forepart of the night was bright and clear it then clouded up and was followed by much thunder and lightning, and towards morning it commenced raining - I went to bed as usual with tent folded and spread on top of blankets, but by the fast coming thunder & lightning I was admonished of the uncertainty of the situation, so I got up and put up my tent in a temporary manner, only to have it fall down when it commenced raining however I secured myself and baggage from Getting wet - It is still raining hard this morning - Horses in sight close by, at about 8 oclock it slacked up and looking fair

39
Sunday August 31 1879
Cold and frosty this morning - Follow up stream about two miles through low bottoms, swampy with Beaver dams, crossing the creek 4 times when I ascend a high Granite point and look down upon a cluster of warm springs, steaming and smoking at its base - The water of these springs emit a good deal of steam, are warm but not very hot - Passing from this through a willow Beaver Marsh of 1/2 mile in extent to the Creek where I cross over to the opposite side and continue through thick timber some distance back and at 10 miles came to a large Marsh through which the stream passes Crossing this marsh, the trial ascends the mountain, for about 3 miles to the summit where we step out of Montana into Idaho Territory - Follow along on this summit about 3 miles, and there descend about the same distance down steep mountain to the Clear Water River, a rapid stream about 30 yds wide running to the left - Follow down this River (after crossing the same) about one quarter of a mile, ascend the mountain on opposite side, to the right, by a Zig Zag route to the top about 3 mile from the base - Thence Westerly along the high divide between the main Clearwater and the main North Fork of the same, road rough, for about 15 mile, when , night coming on I was obliged to camp without grass for the horses - Distance 35 miles
Monday Sept 1 1879
Frosty & Cold - Set out early, country rough and Mountainous, following the main divide today rock & burnt ridges - Saw Deer, Elk, grouse & Fool? chickens in abundance - Passing a few

Saturday August 30 1879
Near this camp is where the Missoula volunteers encamped as per Telegraphic order from Gen Howard to intercept the fleeing Nez Perces while he pressed them from the rear - A solid fener of logs was built across the Canyon at a narrow point and behind it the concentrated gallantry of Missoula and the Bitter Root valley were encamped when the fleeing Nez Perces came in sight - Chief Joseph halted his little Band and went into camp, and there with a flag of truce went down to the fortified Volunteer camp and inquired what they were there for and was quickly answered that they were camped there and had fortified the position to prevent the Chief and his Indians from passing - Humph! says Joseph and returned to his camp - Next day with his warriors all in front and squaws, children, horses & household goods in the rear he marched down the trail to the fortified camp of Volunteers and told them he was going to pass there, and seeing him determined, they stepped one side and let them go - Game is plenty along this Creek, Deer, grouse, pheasants and trout in the stream A heavy frost this morning - Soon enter heavy timbered land and have good travelling for about 3 miles where the trail enters upon rough and hilly ground which Continues all day. The hills often very steep and the trail much obstructed by fallen timber - I camped on the Creek where there is good grass among the small black pine timber - Deer and birds appear along the line of the trail and Elk tracks were seen in a few places Distance 25 miles

40
to my regular bread and bacon - Distance 30 m
Thursday Sept 4 1879
Cold frosty as usual - The weather is so fine the air and water so pure - and game so abundant, that if I could find grass for my horses I would be quite content with short drives, but no grass appearing I am worried about my horses They are starving, getting weaker every day I give them all the advantages there are -- At about 3 miles I came to a marsh of wet land the Grass green but frost bitten - I turned out for the day and hunted, and brought in all the game I needed for some time - I went into Camp at about 8 A.M. Distance 3 miles
Friday Sept 5 1879
Elk, Deer and Fool chickens abound along the road and more particular the latter The stars were still shining dimly when I set out this morning - At 3/4 mile then road or trail crosses a marsh with an indifferent quality of grass - At about 3 miles I came on to a high burnt ridge from which I could see the extensive open bunch grass plains away to the westward about 40 or 50 miles distant on the South side of Clearwater River - The route was hilly, but at 11 AM, began to be more descending and at 1 P.M. I found myself at the bottom of a Canyon at the forks of a stream - I crossed the right hand fork about 30 feet wide and follow down stream west, where the stream bearing off south, leaving the trail entirely at this place, From hence we go crooked over a rough mountain trail S.W. for about 8 miles when we descend to Muscle Creek of about 30 fat, with marshy borders where I camp at

places where water could be obtained, but not a vistage of grass until 3 P.M. came to plenty of wild short damp grass growing upon a high summit, where the snow had lain all summer, or nearly so - The horses eat this grass quite lively and I camped for the night, obtaining water from a spring about 1/2 mile down the the hill to the south - Distance 28 miles
Tuesday Sept 2d 1879
This camp was upon one of the highest summits of this range of Mts - The sun was seen to set in the western horizon last night, and to rise in the East this morning - was up early - It is frosty & cold - The same Kind of rough mountain country continued, the trail leading over high summit peaks and around the sides of lofty mountains, through green timber principally and at 10 A.M. came to a small grassy marsh on the left of the road, with a little pond of water in the middle of it - On account of the horses I concluded to camp here until tomorrow. The grass was quite plenty enough for my two horses and they seemed to relish it Distance today 10 miles --
Wednesday Sept 3d 1879
Followed the same rough and hilly divide all day, good spring water at intervals Saw plenty of game - At 7 miles passed over a high bald ridge of pretty good burch grass and water - continued on about 23 miles and seeing no grass further and night coming on, and my riding horse giving out I camped for the night and tied my Animals to trees - I am faring well, an abundance of game all the time in addition

41
the bluffs in very nearly the same manner that the road descends on the opposite side, for about 4 mile, to the open country unclear, follow on about 2 miles further and camp on a dry stream. water in unclear Distance 22 miles
Tuesday Sept 9~ 1879
Rained nearly all night and my bedding got quite wet - A good fire at daylight made things more comfortable - At about 9 oclock it cleared off and I set out, leaving the scattering pine timber behind and at about 2 P.M. camp on a brisk little stream of good water running north to the Clear water. The Country today was rolling bunch grass land, rich and productive. water scarce - Distance 20 miles
Wednesday Sept 10~1879. 
It did not look like rain last evening yet I put up my tent and was fortunate in so doing for it rained fearfully towards morning - At daylight it cleared off and froze the mud until it was quite hubly?
I travelled about 15 miles over rolling open pine land to a series of high bluffs and descend for about 3 miles to Lapwai Creek a tributary of Clear water - I follow down the valley of the Creek through a pleasant region settled with Indian farmers for about 5 miles & camp Distance 23 miles
Thursday Sept 11 1879.
Clear night and frosty morning - Follow down stream about one mile and cross a tributary coming in from the south and

5 P.M. Caught trout for supper Distance 29 miles
Saturday Sept 6 ~1879
I think I am now well out of the mountains. along this creek the marshes or low praries alternate with thick evergreen forests, and from information recd before leaving Missoula, I am of the opinion that there will be no more mountains to contend with, and that I will soon be upon a wagon or stage road running from Orofino to Lewiston at the Junction of the Clear Water & Snake Rivers.
I left camp at about 8 oclock and had a good trail along a southerly branch of Muscle Creek, crossing a low timbered summit praries and timber alternating and at 20 miles, I saw a house about 2 miles to the right across level prarie land, and striking off in that direction I found the same to be on the Orofino stage road - Here I camped at 2 P.M. - Killed a couple of Deer and some birds today - Distance 20 miles
Sunday Sept 7 ~1879
Lay in camp - Caught Trout & c?
Monday Sept 8 ~1879
Set out this morning for Lewiston over a very gently rolling stick timbered Country for about 6 miles. Then through a more open country to the high bluffs of the Clear water - where the road descends by a tortuous and steep meete? about 3 miles to the Clear Water River, of about 100 yds wide which is crossed by a Ferry. The road upon the opposite banks ascends

Thomas Daniels vs Agnes E. Daniels - Defendants Depositions suppressed - Defendant ready for trial - Court directed Plaintiff to proceed with his case - when to the surprise of the Court - attys - spectators and all else the attys for the plaintiff arose and announced that they had no evidence at all against Mrs Daniels which was a direct admission that the charges proferred by Mr Daniels against his wife were false, wilful and malicious 
Exlsor? Gibbs on behalf of the Deft Mrs Daniels, offered to produce evidence to disprove all of Plffs charges and take a Decree in her favor in accordance with law and common custom but was silenced by the court who promulgated to the world, the arbitrary, unclear -- tyramed? and undeard of ruling that upon a plaintiff failing to prove his case, the Deft had no rights in court to be respected whatever & therfore dismissed the case

Started early -leaving the river and bear off to the right following up a small branch about 2 miles thence over three summits and descend into "Pleasant Valley" - Thence over a summit and cross Cottonwood - Thence over another Divide and descend to a small branch running N.W. which we follow down about one mile to Pine Creek Passing this Creek five or six miles we were misdirected, and eventually came to the end of our road - Knowing the direction we wished to go to intersect the Mullen road at a given point we struck across the prairies, passing a number of claims recently taken and now occupied, we camped at about 6 P.m. at a spring in the head of a long Coulee - A small bunch of Willows furnishing wood for Camp purposes - We think we made about 32 miles today

Monday July 5 1880
In Company with Walter Bartges I set out for the Pen de Oreille (Pou de ray) Lake, on horseback Follow N.E. unclear valley 4 miles - thence over low divide and descend a dulch to the Tukanon River, 14 miles - Thence over a high divide to Snake River 6 miles, thence across the River of Texas Ferry. THence up a ravine 7 miles and camp at a spring - Day hot & dusty p water & grass poor - Heavy wind squall directly after going into camp - Distance 27 miles
Tuesday July 6~1880
Our horses had gone back on the road about 1 1/2 miles, but were soon brought in and we set out up the gulch about 1 1/2 miles, thence by an "Old Road" to the left over the grassy hills to Willow Creek, a small spring branch running to the west through an Alkali vally

53
Hangman Creek at this point and thence to Spokan Falls about 4 miles distant, thence to Ponderay Lake & thence to Montana
Saturday July 10 1880
A rainy night cloudy morning - proceeded down the creek, along the line of the road and at 1 1/2 miles cross over to the other side, and soon turn to the right up a ravine to the plain above and have the Town of Spokan Falls before us - The Town site? has been held for several years, but not much life to the place, until more recently the Rail Road Company have laid off 320 acres into Town lots and this has appeared to infuse life into it and those the most interested therein prophesy that it will soon rival the most prosperous town in the North West = The vally land on the Spokan generally denominated the "Spokan Plain" is of a gravelly and rocky character, so much so, that it does not appear now that very much of it can be made available for agriculture, hence it hardly appears as if it would make a very large town - The water power is magnificent, yet without a good agricultural backing there is no town in this part of the N.W. the has ever prospered to any very great extent - The town at present contains a Grist & Saw mill and about 400 inhabitants

Friday July 9 1880
Set out early in a Course about N.N.W. across the hills and in about an hour intersected a well beaten wagon road, leading in the direction we wished to go - We knew this was not the Mullen Road, yet it must be very near it, and is running parallel to the same - Follow it to the right, and at about 3 miles came to the banks of a Trele? Lake, on our left, with pine timber on its banks and ducks in the water: Here we stopped a couple of hours, in consequence of a rain storm, but as the rain soon subsided, we packed up and set out, keeping along in sight of the Lake about 2 miles when we enter pine lands, and soon find ourselves on the Mullen Road which we follow a few miles to near the bluffs of Hangman Creek, when we leave said road and bear off to the left, on a more recently opened road leading to the town of Spokan Falls - after leaving the Mullen Road about 8 miles we descend the steep bluffs of the Hangman Creek, and camp - Raining considerable - Grass poor - Here we are upon the line af the N.P.R.R. and hundreds of men and chinamen, carts, wagons, horses & boys may be seen at work all along the line. The survey of said road leaves? the Columbia River at the mouth of Snake River, follows a N.E. course on the South side of Snake River, crossing

54
No settlers within 20 or 30 miles and no travel except a little during the low stage of water in summer, and no trade except a small Indian business, yet it appears to justify the proprietor of the Ferry to keep a man here summer and winter to attend to house, Boats etc, and run the trading post: A quite a quantity of pelltries & furs were collected during the past winter, but I saw nothing that would indicate that it was a very profitable place to carry on such a business as Trading or Ferrying Our object was a pleasant trip of hunting & fishing, but when we got here we found we could get no grass for our horses, could get no boats, and the River and Lake being so remarkably high that all the swamps, marshes & bottom lands were inundated, hence could not proceed up the Lake, and as the best hunting was confined to the low lands, we were forced to conclude to abandon our object and return - The River is about 1/2 mile wide & overflowed far into the timber on each side This is the main "Clarks Fork" of the Columbia heading in the Rocky Mountains, and running Westerly to this point, thence in a north westerly direction and unites with the main Columbia a little north of the 49 parallel in British America - 
Game - Waterfowl and fish is quite abundant on the Rivers & Lakes in this vicinity and constitute good hunting ground, during the low water portion of the year

We passed on up the River on the south side, and at 2 miles left the timber country & enter upon a level grassy plain, and after travelling about 12 miles, rain coming on, we struck off across the plain to our left and camped on the south bank of the River among some pines
Sunday July 11 880
Follow up the plains, along and near the River about 9 miles, when we come to the Toll bridge of Cowly & Ford, where we cross over and bear off to the left across the prairie about 5 miles to a small creek at the margin of the heavy pine timber, We pass this and soon after pass the last house, and following the road about 10 miles, and it raining hard, we camped in open pine woods, without water - Distance 30 miles
Monday July 12 1880
No water to camp by hence no cooking or dishwashing to do this morning - Set out early and at 5 miles, heard the shrill voice of the Loon in the timber to our right, & soon saw a narrow Lake of water which continued along near the road for 4 or 5 miles: Finally passing this, & continuing about 10 miles we came to the Ferry across the Pon de ray River a few miles below the Lake - Here is a Ferry and a trading post - (Sim-a-ack-a-tin not much travel and but little trade

Tuesday July 13 1880
We set out on our return this morning - and were soon in sight of the small Lake mentioned yesterday, when suddenly Walter cried out "a Deer", and looking back a "White Tail", was seen dodging across the road not far behind him - Running back to where the Deer had crossed - he was seen standing not far distant in the brush and dead timber - A quick aim and hasty shot, and the Deer was off - Finding the track a few drops of blood was observed, and at 200 yds the deer was found dead with the bullet hole through his head We dressed our venison, and camped at the lake near by, and hunted a little during the day and evening. Walter saw a deer up near the Lake and that was all the game seen although tracks were quite plenty everywhere = We saw no fish in the Lake, yet they may be found therein, yet it is a shallow Lake & not so well adapted as deeper Lakes = A few Loons were in sight of Camp all the afternoon and evening, and several shots were fired at them at long range - A wing was broke on one that attempted to swim by the Camp, The Lake being about 125 yds wide brought him near us, afterwards they did not attempt to pass us

55
Wednesday July 14 1880
We returned on the road about 20 miles, and camped at the margin of the timber about 10 miles from the Spokan River Found strawberries quite abundant today all along in the pine woods 
Thursday July 15 1880
We have concluded to go up to the Couer de Alene (Cor de lane) Lake, which is the sourse of the Spokan River, lying in the timber about 12 miles S.E. of here, so we struck across the Gently rolling plain and entered heavy pine timber about 3 miles before arriving at the Lake. At the Lower end of the Lake, where the Spokan River leaves the same stands Fort Cor.de.lane, a new 4 company Post established last summer - This Fort and Lake is in Idaho, the West bound any of which Territory forms the East boundary of Washington Territory, crosses the Shokan River about 12 miles west of here  The Fort is beautifully located on a level sandy tract of ground, in a magnificent growth of Pines = The Mullen Road passing up the Spokan on Col de lane River touches at this post, thence up the East side of the Lake two or three miles, thence bears off to the Eastward into heavy pine woods of a hilly character = 
Cor de lane Lake is noted for its abrupt banks - Clear water and fine trout - although the water is

Saturday July 17, 1880
Today was hot and sultry - not a bit of air stirring? on the Lake - We went up about 5 miles further and cross over to the East side and camp
Sunday July 18 1880
We returned down towards the main body of the Lake and turned the bow of our boat up the Cor de lane River, another arm of the Lake of similar character extending off more easterly - We camped in a cave on the south side and were pestered by the moskitoes all night and the only consolation we had was we had a good camp ground and plenty of game and fish
Monday July 19 1880
Went up the Cor-de-lane arm of the Lake about 4 miles, and returned along the north ? side to the Fort, and at 6 P.M took our horses out of the government? herd and packed up, and proceeded down River + camped at "Little Falls, 6 miles below
Tuesday July 20 1880
Set out early and at 7 A.M. was a Cowlys + Fords trading post and found the Toll Bridge had been swept away by the high water the day after we passed over - We therefore were obliged to go own the Shokane River on the north side at a point near the Shokane Falls +

very warm, much too warm for drinking water, yet Speckled and Salmon Trout abound in this Lake in great profusion, and are caught by the soldiers & others in astonishing numbers - We hired a boat and proceeded across to the South side and running into a little cove camped for the night - Day warm & still - Lake smooth - found the tracks of Deer quite numerous along the little short sand beach at our camp - a few ducks and occasionally a Loon seems to be about all the game there is on the water
Friday July 16.1880
At a reasonable hour this morning, we set out along the south shore of the Lake, hunting fishing and shooting as we went along, and soon entered the Inlet of "St Joe" River, an arm of the Lake extending off to the south - we followed up this arm of he Lake about 7 miles and camped on the west side where the same is about 1 1/2 miles wide - The abrupt mountains everywhere terminating at th water edge, so that a camping ground is not easily found Occasionally a duck, white Trout are quite numerous everywhere

house an left of road, where we got good spring water to drink.  at about 5 miles further we camped at a spring about 1/4 mile to the right of road = A small Lake about 1/2 mile distant furnished us amusement for the afternoon, as it contained a large number of Ducks and mud hens: We fired away much ammunition, and secured more game than was needed -
Friday July 23 1880
Good road today water in springs, and small Tule Lakes or ponds, at short Intervals - made about 25 miles and camped on Cow Creek a small stream of about 20 feet running Easterly to Palouse.  Willows? along stream + trout in the same.  Saw sage hens today
Saturday July 24, 1880
Cross the creek and follow down stream about 1 1/2 miles, passing one farm house, where the road turns up the hills to the right, and continues through hilly grassy land for 10 miles, when we descend to a point on Palouse River a general camping ground - good water but no grass near.  From this point campers are obliged to descend one or two hundred feet to the stream over loose precipitous rocks where it is difficult to water stock or descend with animals - A Spring to the right at the foot of cliff in the head? of a little rocky gorge furnishes good supply of water
Leaving this place we turn off to the

cross at a Ferry there - We reached the Ferry 20 miles distant at 4P.M. but found the road more rough a portion of the way, than on the south side of the River - We crossed the Ferry, passed the Town, crossed Hangman Creek, and following the same up stream about 1/2 mile above where we camped on our? way coming up, where we found fine grass and camped for the night

An early start and camp at a spring near the Junction of the Texas Ferry and Mullan Road.

At the request of Mr unknown, we now propose to return the remainder of the way by the Mullan Road and cross Snake River below the mouth of Palouse, to examine the country + prospects for stock sheep ranches

right quite abruptly and afterwards wind up the rocky hills to the left and have hilly and rocky ground, for 14 miles to the bluffs of Snake River.  The descent is long and in places deep not being less than 3 miles from the top to the river below - Cross over the Ferry to the south side of the River, and follow up stream about 3 miles to the mouth of Tucanon, follow up south side of Tucanon about 2 miles + strike off to the right into the hills for grass; travelling two or three miles to a high summit and camp without water - Stopped at a house about 1/2 mile back, but could not even obtain water for ourselves to drink
Sunday July 25 1880
Set out in a course South Easterly for the head? of the McKay hollow, and soon fell upon a very well beaten wagon road, which led in that direction and following the same soon passed over a summit and descended to McKay settlements, and first water we met was a large and excellent spring on the Davis place - Here we stopped Cooked + eat breakfast, and let our horses graze
About 3 miles further down the hollow and then bear off to the left on a branch road and was soon at unknown Home  Found Brother Emery? here from Salt Lake - Had not seen him for several years

Here Bro E engages to work for the winter, but concludes to return with me to Waitsburg get his Tool chest + then return here for good

Saturday Oct 2nd 1880
Took care of Johnson, who seems to have a kind of fear that every thing and every body is going to hurt him - Drs Maston? + Petrisky dressed the leg today!  seems to be doing first rate in every particular
Sunday Oct 3rd 1880
Took care of Johnson - He seems to fret a good deal - makes as much fus over a single hair of the leg which sticks to the bandage, as he would, if a piece of flesh actually gave way - He is a man of many whims, never wakes during the night but what he calls me for some purpose, and oftentimes, matters the most trifling - I sometimes think he is frightened at being alone in the night, he certainly acts that way - And as he frequently complains of being lonesome in the daytime, when there is no occasion for it, I am forced to believe he is timid, on the subject of being left alone -
Monday Oct 4, 1880
Took care of Johnson
The patient at times seems to bear up under his misfortune, but at other times he is downhearted, and when talking with anyone with whom he is acquainted always talks as if he was crying
Tuesday Oct 5 1880
Took care of Johnson
Much trouble today - I tried to

as if poor Johnson was nearly suffocated at one time, and at another time, he appeared nearly out from the influence, and rose up in great agony - West turned pale & large drops of sweat stood out prominent all over his face, but by a great effort managed to endure it until the fractured leg was removed The three professional men named, and George Bartges and myself were the parties in attendance - It seemed like a long and tedious operation One hour and seven minutes, from the time the first incision was made until the leg was dressed, and about 28 minutes from time first incision was made until the parts were separated = Recovering from the effects of the chloroform Johnson seems to be in a suffering condition, he lay upon his bed and Groaned and lamented, until night set in
Friday Oct 1 1880
Bartges volunteered to stay up with Johnson unit midnight last night, as I had been up so continually for so long a time that more rest was required on my part, So I slept until 12.30, when I was awoke and Bartges retired - The better part of the night Johnson under the influence of Morphine became drowsy & slept until daylight - During the day he remained easy and was quiet most of the time -

name unclear + I went to his sheep Ranch towards head of Touchet
